text: JOHN KING: We'll get to that.

But what about the
president's involvement?

Number one, this super PAC
ad is run by-- it's run
by a Super PAC.

It's essentially former
Trump campaign officials

who formed this Super
PAC to protect and defend
the president's agenda.

Now they're jumping in,
and it's noteworthy.

They could have
attacked Ted Cruz.

They could have
attacked Rand Paul.

But they decided to attack a
moderate Republican senator

from Nevada, perhaps the
most vulnerable Republican.

What signal does that
said within the family?

KAROUN DEMIRJIAN: Well
it sends a signal--

it's really interesting
to see this.

So, I mean, I covered Nevada
politics pretty closely
when I was at Las Vegas Sun.

And these sorts of ads, I
mean, there's always very
intense primary contests there.

And the moderate
Republican always comes
out of them winning, basically.

So it may not work as well as
they're hoping with Heller,

because Heller's real concern
is that he's running in a state
that's a bluish state of--
[inaudible] shade of purple.
And he knows that going forward.

And he also can look at a
track record of having survived

these sorts of
primary challenges,

if they find somebody
who doesn't have
as much recognition as he does.

But in general, for the
party, it sends a message

that, if you don't
fall in the party line,

if you start to go more
towards the center,

we are going to come
after you immediately.

And it's more forgivable
to take the stance
of, yeah, full repeal.
Go further to the right.
Go further to the right.

All of this talk about,
let's come together

that we've been
talking about, you

know, in the aftermath
of the Scalise shooting,

and everything like
that, that doesn't apply.

JOHN KING: That
disappeared pretty quickly.

MICHAEL BENDER:
There basically is

no involvement right
now from President
Trump or this White House.

Legislative affairs
team is working
on this behind the scenes.

But Trump has been
pretty hands off,

which is a pretty big
difference from how
they did it in the House.

They've basically put the ball
here in McConnell's court.

As this was moving
from the House,

I had heard from senior White
House-- senior House officials

frustrated by a fledgling White
House trying to get involved

in a process that they
weren't familiar with in the
legislative process.

They were inaccurate
on their vote counts,

if not you know, a certain
amount of credulity
dealing with the Freedom Caucus.

So now they've put this
in McConnell's court.

We could see a push here at
the end from President Trump,
and probably will.

But that's not going to
help them save the blame--
or avoid any blame.

JOHN KING: Not involved in the
detail of the negotiations,

yet involved in the
political context about this.

And so to Manu's point, if
you're a Republican and you

might have to cast a
potentially career changing,

and for some potentially
career ending,

vote in three or
four days, first,

you have the president
tweeting yesterday,

I cannot imagine that these very
fine Republican senators would

allow the American
people to suffer
broken Obamacare any longer.
OK.

Relatively just a little nudge
to Republican senators here.

But here, he does an
interview this morning
with Fox and Friends.

And he's asked about a Facebook
posting that former President

Obama put up, essentially
saying, you know,

what the Republicans are
trying to do is mean.

Listen to the
President's answer.

DONALD TRUMP: Well he
actually used my term, mean.
That was my term.
Because I want to see--

I want to see-- and I
speak from the heart.
That's what I want to see.
I want to see a bill with heart.

JOHN KING: He actually
used my term, mean.

That's-- the president had a
Rose Garden celebration saying

the House passed
bill was the greatest
thing since sliced bread.
Then he called it mean.

If you're a House member, and
you cast that vote, guess what?

Those words are coming back
to get you in a political ad.

If you're a senator who has
to decide this this week,

and you see, now the president
confirming-- remember,

the White House said, oh,
that's not what he meant.

Then they ran out there to say,
he didn't really mean mean.

Now the President is actually
confirming I called it mean.

What confidence do you
have if you're a senator

or about to cast this
vote that the president,

who has sway with the
Republican base and his base,
has your back?
MARGARET TALEV: Yeah.

The message you can take away is
that they're playing hardball,

that right now, the focus is on
the politics, not the policy.

And that this is, in
many ways, the Senate
version of what the House did.

And the messaging for that was,
let's just get a bill passed.

And we can work out what
the real bill is later.

So again, a repeat of
this, asking senators

to go on the board
with something

that is not going to be,
ultimately, in the end,
what passes.
And that's part of the problem.

And I agree that, the
only way to do this
is to bring the right in.
OK.
But to bring the right in.
JOHN KING: But if--

the stakes are
very different now.

Because if the
Senate passes a bill,

the message will back
to the House will be,
you have to pass the same bill.
We can't go through this again.

And so then you're
changing health care law.
Then you're changing law.

And if you look at
the Senate bill--

I just want to
put this up there,
because the policy matters.

Yes, this is not a full
repeal of Obamacare,
what the Senate is looking at.

It would repeal
the taxes created.

It would repeal some
of the subsidies
for out-of-pocket costs.

It would repeal the
individual mandate,
and repeal the employer mandate.

So that part of Obamacare
gets pulled out.

It would change
Medicaid expansion.

That's what the moderates
say goes too far.

Conservatives say it
doesn't go too far enough.
Changes some of the tax credits.

It would allow states
waivers on that big question
of essential health benefits.

What must be covered in your
health insurance policy?

It takes away Obamacare
prohibitions on annual lifetime
limits on insurance coverage.

A lot of people don't like
that because the states

could opt out and
essentially restrict people.

And it changes health
savings account rules.

It keeps the preexisting
conditions policy roughly.
There are some changes there.

And you can stay on your
parents' health insurance

until you're 26.
That's roughly the same.

Keep might be a little
bit strong there.

But the policy here matters,
because if the Senate passes

this bill, the argument is,
then you go to the House

and you say, we
can't change this.

We just got this
through the Senate.

Mike Pence would likely have
to cast a tie breaking vote.
Do it or not.

Mark Meadows out at this
[inaudible] retreat,

was saying two amendments, they
could have this whole thing
done by July 4th.

I suspect that's
a tad optimistic.
MANU RAJU: Very optimistic.

You got to get it out
of the Senate first.

And that's still going
to be very difficult.
But I think the--

what was remarkable to
hear President Trump

acknowledge that he called
the health care bill mean.

The problem for him is
that he does not-- he's
not ideological about this.

He does not have
a really firm view

about how he wants the
health care system to look--
what he wants it to look like.

But, there are members
of Congress who do.

They feel very,
very passionately
about health care policy.

And they have a very
staunch, ideological view

about the direction
that this is going.

People like Rand Paul, who
believe that the subsidies

in-- the tax credits in this
bill will be more generous,

and will actually be more
expensive than the subsidies
in Obamacare.

These are fundamental
policy questions

that the White House,
the president himself,
does not want to engage in.

A key question, of
course, is going

to be when the
Congressional Budget

Office releases the estimate
as early as Monday, Tuesday.
How does that affect the vote?

Even more, it could
be pretty bad.

JOHN KING: Cause then,
you'll have a number

saying how many
millions of Americans
lose their health coverage.
What this does to the deficit.
Do premiums go up?

Especially, one of
the big questions

here for the
president, does he turn

on this piece of
legislation when

he sees that many Trump
voters, elderly Americans,
may have their premiums go up.

So, this tight compact
schedule this week.
But, several chapters as we go.
